job_title: Lecturer in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros: Good holiday allowance through the year.
cons: Quality of leadership and management inconsistent across college. If lucky, then you would get a great department head, if no, then life turns into misery.

review_title: Has it's challenges, but overall a great place to work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros: Great people who are truly student-focused. An excellent holiday entitlement and pension scheme. Good development opportunities are available for those who are willing to put in the hard work. Apprenticeships and funded training and development is available. Hybrid working is available so better work-life balance. Excellent facilities in a modern environment with access to on-site catering and discounted spa facilities.
cons: On-site parking is an issue and being city centre, space is as at a premium to develop the site further. As the workforce grows, this is going to become even more of a challenge. Senior leadership can sometimes be too far removed from the frontline student facing roles, but they ultimately are the final decision makers, so important decisions are not always made in the best interest of staff and spending is highly scrutinised but not always in the right areas. Individual departments can sometimes be too focused on their own work, so cross department working and communication is sometimes poor. Post-covid, recruitment has been an issue as it has for many companies, which has resulted in some understaffing, so some departments are over-stretched.

review_title: The worst place I have ever worked.
job_title: Access and Particpation Officer in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros: I cannot think of a single positive.
cons: I could easily list multiple reasons for leaving Bradford College. I can comfortably say working at Bradford College has been the worst experience of my career. The college as a whole is a toxic environment, allowing a culture of bullying to thrive amongst staff, making it an unbearable place to work. Very few staff members actually care about the students, and instead focus their energy on complaining, putting down other members of staff and refusing to take accountability for their work. The consistent restructuring creates a sense of uncertainty, and leaves behind a chaos of confusion. The “low level staff” (as we have been referred to as) are left to feel overworked, underpaid and undervalued. Personally, having worked here for just over two years and experiencing three restructures/redundancies within my department, I found it extremely difficult to maintain motivation and a positive attitude towards my work. Management do not take the time to understand you and your role and neglect to support your work. Professional development opportunities are very limited and of poor quality, and there is little opportunity for progression in an institute like this. Not only have I felt unsupported in my work, but also as an employee with a disability, I spent my first few months here chasing HR for support in working with a disability, help with making reasonable adjustments and occupational health support. After being consistently ignored I had no choice but to give up. This was extremely disappointing and unacceptable. The list of negatives is extensive and personally, I don’t see Bradford College improving and would never return to such an awful place of work.

review_title: Some great people that I am proud to know
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros:
My fellow lecturers. I have never worked with so many people that are so prepared to put so much of themselves into their work. Teaching is a very hard and demanding job but my colleagues keep on putting their heart and soul into the task. I have never worked with such a high proportional who are so committed to their jobs.
This college has done a marvously work in the city of Bradford which has many needs.
cons:
Undoubtly the upper managerment. This college has been driven into disaster from having money in the bank to having large debts. Staff have had to put up with only a one off 1% pay rise in ten years while the executive have seen large rises. We don't know how much exactly becase they won't tell us despite been asked to divulge the details many times. They never consult staff or listen to them - ever.
I could say much more there decision making skills and about how the college has been run into the ground but had better leave at this stage for now.

review_title: Used to be a great place
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros: Public sector benefits like flexi-time, above average holidays, sick pay, etc. You can get subsidised parking if you live enough miles away, or car share. Used to be a great place to work but not now.
cons: After years of bad management it's the people at the bottom who lose their jobs, not the ineffective management. Over 200 made redundant recently and has had years of no replacement of staff policy which has reduced staff numbers by a third - but you still have to do the same amount of work. No pay rises for years but again the senior management would often gift themselves 10% pay rises.

job_title: Lecturer in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros: All colleagues are fantastic to work with and the middle management give lots of autonomy to allow you to get on with your job.
cons: Senior Management are disconnected from the rest of the college and are unable to make decisions. There is a lack of strategy and communication from the top leaving you feeling unable to move anything forward.

job_title: IAG Manager in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros: Great colleagues and supportive peer environment. New facilities a benefit to the local environment, staff and students. Some very hard working, dedicated individuals who will do so much to support their students
cons: Lack of support from senior management. Lack of vision and purpose, overshadowed by empire building. Restructure has resulted in decimation of student facing services as vital posts gone and replaced by top heavy management. It's a shame to witness the change
